facts.text: S.V.N. Nanappa Naicker and his sons were adjudged insolvents on an application of Smt. Engammal (respondent).
Insolvents preferred appeal to Madras High Court, dismissed on April 17, 1953.

Official receiver took steps to sell insolvents' property: lot 1 - 145 acres 10 cents dry land and masonry house; lot 2 - 8 acres odd dry land. Both subject to mortgage with encumbrance of Rs. 17,200/- total.

Auction fixed for September 28, 1953. Fifteen creditors present including respondent's son. No request for postponement. Highest bid lot 1: Rs. 4500/- by appellant (brother-in-law of Nanappa Naicker); lot 2: Rs. 70/- by appellant. Total Rs. 4570/-.
Official receiver did not close sale on Sept 28, hoping higher offers; postponed to various dates up to October 26, 1953. Respondent's son present on all dates, no higher offer from respondent.
On October 26, 1953, respondent applied to postpone sale for three months due to drought and low prices for agricultural lands.
Official receiver refused postponement as no higher offer from respondent, knocked down properties to appellant.

On November 18, 1953, respondent applied under s. 68 Provincial Insolvency Act to set aside sale: inadequate price due to drought, stringency in money market; hoped for Rs. 15,000/- exclusive of encumbrances if postponed; offered to bid > Rs. 7500/-; alleged collusion between official receiver, insolvent and appellant.
Subordinate Judge allowed respondent's application under s.68: price low, prejudices general body of creditors.

District Judge allowed appeal under s.75: no irregularity in conduct of sale; no collusion; respondent's son present but no higher bid; price not low (criticized Sub Judge's valuation based on doubling mortgage amount from 1936 Rs.20,000/-; insolvent's Rs.80,000/- valuation exaggerated; annual deposit Rs.2000/- not basis for income valuation).

Revision to High Court under proviso to s.75. Respondent offered Rs.9,000/- deposit for fresh auction starting bid Rs.9,000/- + Rs.1,000/- to appellant. High Court accepted offer though price not unconscionably low but low considering extent/nature; creditors get more dividend; allowed revision.
Offer made three years after 1953 auction.
Insolvents in possession during pendency of insolvency appeal, depositing Rs.2000/- annually per High Court order.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction to interfere with the District Judge's order under proviso to s.75 without concluding that it was not according to law.
Scope of court's power under s.68 to interfere with official receiver's sale under s.59A: grounds like fraud, collusion, irregularity, or grossly inadequate price.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court had no jurisdiction to interfere unless District Judge's order not according to law; High Court did not apply mind to this, carried away by respondent's offer of Rs.9,000/- made three years later (prices may have risen).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s.75 Provincial Insolvency Act

respondent_arguments.text: Court's power under s.68 (in appeal from receiver's act) wider than in execution auction sales; Subordinate Judge right to set aside sale; High Court right to restore that.

court_reasoning.text: Power under s.68 is judicial, exercised on well-recognised principles; grounds for interfering with receiver's s.59A sale: fraud/collusion, irregularities affecting price, or price so low as to justify not selling at that price; priority: creditors first, insolvent second, purchaser third; but not arbitrary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No fraud/collusion (found by both lower courts); no irregularity; price not shown low by proper valuation minus encumbrance.

court_reasoning.text: Subordinate Judge's finding of low price flawed: no proper valuation (doubled 1936 mortgage; ignored exaggeration in Rs.80,000/-; Rs.2000/- deposit not income proof); District Judge correctly reversed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence price inadequate/unreasonable; respondent could have valued properly or bid higher.

court_reasoning.text: High Court did not consider if District Judge's order according to law; impressed by 3-year later offer (prices may risen); no jurisdiction to interfere.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court remarked price not unconscionably low but still low vs. 1956 offer.

court_reasoning.text: Supreme Court cannot find price low: no proper valuation or encumbrance details on record; District Judge's order according to law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Insufficient material to say appellant's price low in 1953 circumstances.

holdings.text: High Court lacked jurisdiction under proviso to s.75 without finding District Judge's order not according to law; order set aside, District Judge's restored.
To interfere under s.68 with receiver's sale, need judicial grounds: fraud/collusion/irregularity/grossly inadequate price proven by proper valuation net of encumbrance; none here.

statutes_cited.name: Provincial Insolvency Act, No. V of 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: s.68: court control over receiver's acts (sale set aside if justified); s.59A: receiver's power to sell; s.75: appeal to District Judge, High Court revision if order not according to law.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dated July 27, 1956 set aside; District Judge's order restored, confirming sale to appellant.
outcome.relief_granted: Sale to appellant confirmed; no fresh auction.

key_quotes.text: "the power under s. 68 is a judicial power and must be exercised on well recognised principles, justifying interference with an act of the receiver"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "there must be judicial grounds on which the court will act in setting aside the sale decided upon by the official receiver."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the High Court did not consider the question whether the order of the District Judge was according to law or not."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for setting aside High Court order.
